title: £50k being offered to families to move to picturesque Alpine village - Leicester Mercury
text:

Ever fancied living in Europe? With Brexit looming it could be about to get a lot more difficult. 
But if you're quick you might be able to take up an incredible offer from a picturesque Alpine village. 
People living in Albinen, located in the southwestern part of Switzerland, are taking a vote on whether they should pay for others to join them. 
The village has been struggling to cope with an exodus of permanent residents, reports Finance.co.uk. 
Many of the properties left have been bought up as holiday homes. Read More Man's wife 'shocked' after he decorates his house with TIN FOIL for Christmas 
And when three families recently moved out, taking eight children with them, the local school had to close down. 
But those left have come up with a plan - an offer that some might find it difficult to turn down. The hills could be alive for you just like Julie Andrews 
Residents are to vote on the idea of PAYING new families to come and live in the village, situated in the Alps near Leukerbad in Valais. 
Families who decide to build or buy a house in the village could be given a payment amounting to £19,000 for each adult and £7,600 for each child. Read More 
So a family of four could net themselves £53,000 to make the relocation. What's the catch? 
There are a few conditions. New residents must be under the age of 45, and they must stay for at least ten years. 
The house they build or buy has to be worth at least £152,000, and it must be their primary residence. Albinen 
Villagers hope the they would benefit in return from the initial outlay through construction contracts and taxes.
